post_info.post_title: How much gun control should there be?

"Gun control" is an illegal and unConstitutional fiction for hoplophobes to cling to instead of sucking their fingers or thumb.

Since this website involves a paid subscription, I posted the entire article. However one might be able to actually see this article by clicking on the link. This could be a back door to a paid subscription. emoticon_smile
   Judge says Chicago gun law case just one of many important cases U.S. Supreme Court will consider  
Laws that make it difficult for Americans to own or possess guns aid criminals by making it harder for law abiding citizens to have access to the weapons, a judge said Friday.
 
 "The criminals who are carrying guns aren't following the registration laws to begin with," 3rd District Court of Appeals Judge John Willamowski said Friday.
 Willamowski spoke to Republicans at their monthly luncheon Friday about cases that soon will be heard before the U.S. Supreme Court. One case he talked about was a group challenging the gun ban in Chicago that has so many restrictions it makes it nearly impossible for law-abiding people to own or possess guns.
 
 "The only ones the registration laws affect are the non criminals, which is kind of illogical," he said.
 
 Two other courts have upheld the ban. This case is the first to go before the nation's highest court since its historic ruling last yearX that found a gun ban in Washington D.C. was unconstitutional.
 
 The issues are similar but involve state rights mixed with the Second Amendment which gives citizens the right to keep and bear arms.
 
 Willamowski expects the side opposing the gun ban will argue those seeking to legally have guns are not the ones who get in trouble. Those people also are the ones the gun ban hurts the most since the criminals are going to carry regardless of the law.
 
 "There will be a lot of Second Amendment folks watching that," he said.
 
 Willamowski briefly mentioned other cases such as whether the government has the right to impose a life-in-prison sentence to a juvenile in a case that does not involve a murder.

It looks like the controllers have hitched their wagons to the wrong set of horses. 
 
   Soldiers wary of often corrupt Mexican police  
MONTERREY, Mexico - When soldiers tried to halt a suspicious-looking SUV that was being escorted through Monterrey by a state policeman, the officer radioed for backup. In minutes, police from 40 patrol cars surrounded the troops, drawing their guns and sending the soldiers diving for cover in an hour-long standoff.
 
 Confrontations like that are happening with increasing frequency in Mexico's wealthiest city as soldiers fight corrupt police officers helping drug cartels - in addition to taking on the drug dealers themselves.
 
 This year alone, police and soldiers have confronted one another more than 65 times, The Associated Press has learned - a growing and dangerous trend in the war on drugs.

 As the gun control minions walk into the Wicked Witch of the West's castle, they sing.

Safer Streets 101: stopping outlaws and not freedoms. 
 The substance of the second amendment isn't in the concept of guns per se, it is in the concept of being the sovereign in America and, as the sovereign, having the legal and moral monopoly on all lethal force here. The key word is sovereignty.
 
 When we think of safer streets, we often make that same mistake in concept (what do you mean we Kemosabe?) Many believe that our major cities' streets are unsafe due to so many guns on the street, but there are just as many guns on the streets in right-to-carry states without the high crime rate. What gives? What is the subject of gun control missing here?
 
 The answer is that it is not that major cities have too many guns, the major cities have too many Outlaws. Major cities in RTC states have fewer outlaws because they have more guns, not fewer guns. The real difference is not measured in guns, but in fewer laws. That is to say, less gun control becomes more crime control.

 Gun control is NOT crime control!

I'd say a limited amount of gun control is more like crime control. As long as violent criminals, drug addicts, and people with mental disorders don't have firearms, we shouldn't have to worry too much.

 This was written by a law professor at UCLA dealing with 'free speech' which is the same as any other right that calls for free exercise and you could put guns in place of speech and he has and will continue to do so. He writes: The failure to stand up for free expression emboldens those who would attack and undermine it. It is time for colleges and universities in particular to exercise moral and intellectual leadership. It is incumbent on those responsible for the education of the next generation of leaders to stand up for certain basic principles: that the free exchange of ideas is essential to liberal democracy; that each person is entitled to hold and express his or her own views without fear of bodily harm; and that the suppression of ideas is a form of repression used by authoritarian regimes around the world to control and dehumanize their citizens and squelch opposition. - Prof. Eugene Volokh
 
 To paraphrase Ben Franklin, those who would give up essential liberty to purchase a little temporary safety, will get neither liberty nor safety.

 Recent Federal laws.
 1.Brady background checks for all handgun buyers, 
 2.institution of the waiting period,
 3. Making it illegal for anyone under 18 to own or even possess a handgun.
 4. The President's executive order stopping the importation of many guns,
 5. Excessive fees and regulations that drove many legitimate gun shop owners out of business.
 6. The widening of Brady to include background checks from just handguns to include all new firearm purchases. 
 7. Insta Check! 
 8. Additional disqualification's and changes to legal firearms purchases on form 4473, 
 9. The assault weapons ban. Sunset
 10. The ten round magazine, Sunset
 11 Lautenburg.
 12 just recently the NICS improvement act!
 
   The "Unregulated" Gun  
 "Gun Laws of America is 384 pages of just the federal statutes that regulate guns-more than 88,000 words. Additionally, the associated federal regulations interpreting these laws are even larger. Minimum penalty for a violation is typically 5 years in federal prison for every offense.
 
 It is estimated that there are between 22,000 and 30,000 gun laws on the books in America. Those laws include restrictions on possession, carry, distribution, storage, transfer, manufacture, sale, ownership, importation, use and more.
